5. e e e Delellelels et

. dlSt e T T W



e



Planned Development

Private: The Locke Insulator Co. gained
approval in 1982 to fill 1.5 acres of shore-
line to expand its plant. The added land
will allow the company to remain at its cur-
rent site and add approximately 100 new
jobs. To compensate for its expansion into
existing water area, the company has
created a new wetland of comparable size
at Reedbird Park further south on the
Middle Branch.

Public: A great many public improve-
ments are programmed for the South
Baltimore peninsula, most of them in con-
junction with the construction of the Inter-
state 95 expressway.



*Interstate 95 - The completion of this
1-1/2-mile segment of roadway, which
will connect the existing Hanover
Street interchange to the roadway in
Canton and will include the eight-lane,
Fort McHenry Tunnel, represents the
final link in an expressway connecting
Baltimore’s harbor to the entire east
coast. This final segment costing over
$800 million will be completed in two
phases. In December 1982 the roadway
was opened from Hanover Street to
Key Highway, and by 1985 from Key
Highway across the harbor to Canton.
Coupled with the highway construc-
tion there have been improvements to
McComas Street and the installation of
noise barriers and earth mounds to
shield the Francis Scott Key Public
School and Latrobe Park from highway
noise.

*B & O Riverside Yard - The locomotive
service and maintenance center for all
B & O operations in Baltimore has been
relocated for the construction of Inter-
state 95. As a result the B& O has built
a new maintenance shop, oil storage
tank, and internal service road.

*Locust Point North Marine Terminal -
The Maryland Port Administration has
scheduled improvements to several
piers at its north terminal. In the next
few years, a wooden pier will be
replaced with a steel and concrete
structure, an old shed will be demo-
lished, and existing piers will be paved
and lighting installed.

*Hull Street Park - Though close to the
water, the Locust Point community has
no direct public access to the harbor.
Most of the shoreline is devoted to

“industrial, port, and rail activities. To
give the community an opportunity to

enjoy the shoreline, the City converted

the northern end of Hull Street into a
small park with a pier for docking
boats and for fishing. The project was
completed in 1984.

Construction of the Fort McHenry Tunnel



*Southern High School Playfield - Con-
structed in mid-1983 on land just to
the east of the school the playfield will
provide a football practice field and a
track and field area.

*Wetlands - In return for decreasing the
water area of the harbor by filling in
the shoreline at the Canton-Seagirt site
with spoil from the Fort McHenry
Tunnel dredging, a 5.3-acre, land-
scaped wetland area will be created in
a cove adjacent to Fort McHenry. The
marsh, which will provide a habitat for
wetland plants and animals, will be
enclosed by a submerged stone dike.



|ssues and Problems

Port-Related Issues: Two concerns face
the Maryland Port Administration’s cargo
handling operations at the North and South
Locust Point Terminals. First, there is
insufficient storage space for incoming and
outgoing cargo. As a consequence, export
cargo must be held in other parts of the
City and then hauled to the terminal when
the appropriate ship arrives. This is both
costly and inefficient. Import cargo must be
immediately loaded onto trucks and rail
cars, creating scheduling difficulties. The
scarcity of available storage space limits the
number of ships the Locust Point terminals
are able to handle.

A second concern which faces the
South Locust Point Terminal and adjoining
industries is the possible adverse effect of
the new expressway on the available “stack-
ing”’ and manuevering space for trucks. A
busy marine terminal requires considerable
space where trucks waiting to load or
unload cargo can line up. The Interstate
Division of Baltimore City, the Port Admin-
istration, and local industries have worked
to accommodate these concerns and allow
for the construction of Interstate-95 and

the Fort McHenry Tunnel. Actual operation
of the terminal with the completed high-
way will test these solutions.

While not as critical to South Balti-
more’s port activities as to port activities
elsewhere on the harbor, dredging the
harbor’s main channel from its current
depth of 42 feet to a new depth of 50 feet
might benefit the grain operation on Pier 7
at the Locust Point North Terminal.

Traffic and Parking Problems: The resi-
dential communities of South Baltimore
and Locust Point have long faced the
annoying problem of truck traffic on local
residential streets. This problem should be
somewhat reduced by the new internal
road linking North and South Locust Point
Marine Terminals constructed by the Port
Administration.

Environmental Issues: The most signifi-
cant environmental issue in the South
Baltimore area is air pollution. Like all the
heavily industrialized areas around the
port, South Baltimore has been classified by
the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency
as a “‘non-attainment area” for airborne
particles. These particles, or suspended par-

ticulates, are very fine and are released into

the air by industrial processes, vehicle
exhausts, construction and demolition activ-
ities, vacant, unkept land, loading, unload-
ing, and storage of dry bulk goods. Inhal-
ing these particles, especially over a long
period of time, can lead to severe respira-
tory problems and damage to the lungs.
The problem should be significantly
reduced once,the extensive construction
work is completed on Interstate 95 in 1985.
However, full and effective control of the
problem will also require technological
innovations making it economically practi-
cal to control the particulate pollution pro-
duced by grain and other bulk material
transfer operations and the many acres of
railyards in Locust Point.



/5

Maryland Port Administration

Maryland Port Administration
